dt: {bc}to emit quick flashes as if throwing off sparks {bc}{sx|sparkle||}

dt.t: Imagine it's a cool summer night, the stars {wi}scintillate{/wi} brilliantly in the sky overhead and the campfire blazes away.

dt: {bc}to dazzle or impress with liveliness or wit

dt.t: The Jay Tarses sitcom, which {wi}scintillates{/wi} with whacked-out wit, was dropped by NBC in 1988 because it was deemed too quirky.

Mrs. Burnett's discussion of the Orestes leads the way to a new interpretation of Euripides' Apolline solution, a solution which has titillated, puzzled and infuriated generations of scholars. The arguments {wi}scintillate{/wi}, but sometimes are pushed too far.

dt: {bc}to throw off as a spark or as sparkling flashes

et: Latin {it}scintillatus{/it}, past participle of {it}scintillare{/it} to sparkle, from {it}scintilla{/it} spark
shortdef: to emit quick flashes as if throwing off sparks : sparkle
to dazzle or impress with liveliness or wit
